No. Take Japan as an example (it has by far the highest debt to GDP ratio of any country), yet it remains a leading global exporter of tech and commodities. It’s a producer and net exporter of basic goods like clothing and raw materials, and it’s home to large, global conglomerates like Fast Retailing Co. (market cap of $50B).  The important consideration isn’t what a country’s debt to GDP ratio is, but whether that country will continue to be able to service its debts in the future. If a country continues to produce and maintain an environment that fosters production (keep effective tax rates low, attract corporations, make it easy for entrepreneurs to start businesses, maintain legal systems that minimize transaction costs, etc.), then a high ratio of government debt to GDP won’t necessarily choke a country’s economic performance.

It has the potential to be very bad because of the pandemic. Currently, the US economy, like many other economies, is limping along with output down by perhaps 10%, and no real relief in sight until maybe early summer next year, if we get a good vaccine soon. The current budget deficit is over $3T, and likewise won’t improve until the economy comes back, which will take longer. Repaying those trillions of dollars will not be easy. There are only three options - raise taxes, cut expenditures, or print money and hope inflation makes the problem go away (or some combination). The real economic activity that has been lost during the pandemic is gone forever, the stock market is being sustained by quantitative easing (printing money), and will collapse when that stops, as stop it must sometime. The real eceonomic activity needed to sustain current stock valuations is simply not there. The next administration will have major problems dealing with this.
